newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ economists' growth expectations rise - survey.
newsitem.headline: NZ economists' growth expectations rise - survey.

text.p: New Zealand economists expect the rate of growth of real GDP in a year's time to rise to 2.77 percent, up from their forecast in July of 2.25 percent, according to a survey by the Alexander Consulting Group.
Production-based GDP in the year to June grew an actual 2.6 percent.
The Alexander Economists Survey, published on Wednesday, also showed a rise in expectations for the New Zealand dollar Trade-Weighted Index, compared to the group's July survey.
The TWI was picked at 65.5 in a year's time, up from the economists' average expectation in July of 64.9. It is currently at 67.6.

The inflation rate, as measured by the Consumers Price Index, was seen at 1.14 percent a year out. In July, the economists had on average picked headline inflation at 1.49 percent in a year's time. In the September year it was 2.4 percent.
The average weekly wage was seen growing at a rate of 2.82 percent, compared to 2.72 percent.

The economists' forecasts for real interest rates a year out slipped very slightly in October. They now see the yield on 10-year government stock, in excess of inflation, at 6.14 percent in a year's time, against their July forecast of 6.19 percent.
The stock is currently yielding 7.39 percent, while annual underlying inflation was at 2.34 percent in the September year. ----------------------------------------------------------------
1 year's time 4 years' time 7 years' time
Note: asterisked figures are the result of the Alexander Consulting Group's July 1996 survey.
The October survey canvassed 17 New Zealand banks, investment managers and forecasting groups.
